sub.page.title: Structural Axioms of the Real Number System

block.para: Here is a plain listing of the structural axioms of the real number system \RNr.
Algebraic Structure of \RNr \RNr is a set, whose elements are called real numbers, with two distinguished elements 0 and 1, 0\neq 1. On \RNr we have two operations

li.para: Addition given by a function \StPrdct{\RNr}{\RNr} \longrightarrow \RNr, whose value on a pair (x,y) is denoted x+y.
Multiplication given by a function \StPrdct{\RNr}{\RNr} \longrightarrow \RNr, whose value on a pair (x,y) is denoted x\cdot y or just xy.

block.para:
These operations satisfy the following
structural axioms
These axioms say that \RNr is a field. .

li.para: Associativity of addition: a+(b+c) = (a+b)+c for all a,b,c\in \RNr.
Commutativity of addition: a+b = b+a for all a,b\in \RNr.
Neutrality of 0 with respect to addition: a+0=a=0+a for all a\in \RNr.
Existence of additive inverses: For all a\in \RNr, there exists b\in \RNr such that a+b=0=b+a.
Associativity of multiplication: a\cdot (b\cdot c) = (a\cdot b)\cdot c for all a,b,c\in \RNr.
Commutativity of multiplication: a\cdot b = b\cdot a for all a,b\in \RNr.
Neutrality of 1 with respect to multiplication: a\cdot 1=a=1\cdot a for all a\in \RNr.
Existence of multiplicative inverses: For all 0\neq a\in \RNr, there exists b\in \RNr such that a\cdot b=1=b\cdot a.
Distributivity: a\cdot (b+c) = ab\ +\ ac, for all a,b,c\in \RNr.

block.para:
Ordering structure of \RNr Certain pairs x,y\in\RNr satisfy the relationship
x\leq y
Read: ‘x is less than or equal to y.’
or, equivalently,
y\geq x
Read: ‘y is greater than or equal to x.’ . We also say x < y , read: ‘x is less than y’ or, equivalently, y > x , if x\leq y and x\neq y. This relationship has the following
properties
These properties say that \RNr is a totally ordered set. .

li.para: Reflexivity: x\leq x for all x\in \RNr.
Transitivity: if x\leq y and y\leq z, then x\leq z, for all x,y,z\in \RNr.
Antisymmetry: if x\leq y and y\leq x, then x=y, for all x,y\in \RNr.
Totality: for all x,y\in \RNr, x\leq y or y\leq x.

block.para: Moreover, addition and multiplication in \RNr are required to be compatible with the ordering structure by the properties below.

li.para: If x\leq y, then x+z\leq y+z for all x,y,z\in \RNr.
If 0\leq x,y, then 0\leq x\cdot y for all x,y\in \RNr.

Completeness of \RNr Informally speaking, this axiom asserts that the real number system does not have any ‘gaps’ between numbers. In rigorous language: whenever A,B are nonempty subsets of \RNr with a\leq b for all a\in A and all b\in B, then there exists x\in \RNr with

math.display.latex: a \leq x\leq b,\quad \text{for all}\quad a\in A,\ \ b\in B.
